attributes.comment:
The size of the increase proposed by USCIS is both unreasonable and
unwarranted by the performance of the Service. The Service claims repeatedly
that they have eliminated their backlog, and achieved six month processing times
on most cases - both of these claims are demonstrably false. To use either of
these claims to justify higher fees perpetrates a lie to Congress and to the
petitioners and applicants who must go to the Service to obtain benefits.

The Service "eliminated" several million pending I-130 applications from their
backlog not by adjudicating these files, but by removing any I-130 that was not
current from their backlog count. These I-130s all must still be adjudicated, but
the Service conveninently pretends that this day will never come - meanwhile,
more I-130s continue to be filed, and the size of this phantom backlog climbs
higher. In addition, the Service removes from their backlog count any petition or
application that is on hold due to security checks or background checks.
Thousands of cases have delayed background checks, and this number only gets
larger over time. The Service should be required to include all pending cases in
their backlog count, and not manipulate this data to justify the fee increases.

The Service claims that it is processing cases in 6 months, yet thousands of
applicants for green cards and for naturalization know that their real processing
time for cases is 2, 3, 4 years or more. There is no sanction on the Service if it
does not meet its promised 6 month processing "goal", and only those applicants
who have had the resources and the courage to sue the Service for action have
been able to find any meaningful way out of long-delayed background check
limbo. Before demanding more fees from new applications, the Service should be
required to clear all pending applications that have been on hold for one year
solely due to a delayed background check from the Federal Bureau of
Investigations (FBI). If the background check cannot be cleared, the Service
should be required to explicitly advise the applicants when this will be resolved.

More importantly, the Service's justification that higher fees are necessary to
cover the costs of security and background checks is unfair and unreasonable to
pass on to applicants. While security issues are understandably greater now,
these are not part of the benefit that applicants are requesting. To the contrary,
the background checks are a national concern and an administrative cost that
must be covered by Congress. The Service requires cases to pend for years while
their background checks languish at the Service and the FBI, yet we allow most of
these applicants and beneficiaries to live and work in the U.S. while their cases
are in process - either these individuals are not a threat to security, or the Service
and the FBI are willing to gamble that they are a threat, but they won't do any
damage while they wait for the cases to be processed.

Appropriate inflationary increases in fees are one thing, but the size of this
increase is ecessive and in appropriate - the Service will lock out millions of
applicants for naturalization and other benefits who cannot afford the new fees.
We will have to revise Emma Lazarus's words accordingly: "Give me your tired,
your rich, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free." The Service's new fee
schedule is a perversion of the long-standing tradition of welcoming the immigrant,
and not using fees and other costs to lock out the poor who would come to the
U.S. to find their fortune and their future.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Grace Hoppin
